Package com.google.mu.util

Class CaseBreaker

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.mu.util.CaseBreaker
  • public final class CaseBreaker
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility class to break input strings (normally identifier strings) in camelCase, UpperCamelCase, snake_case, UPPER_SNAKE_CASE, dash-case etc.

    By default, non-alphanum ascii characters are treated as caseDelimiter characters and are treated the same as any case delimiter. Lower case characters and digits are considers to be lower-case when breaking up camel case.

    If the default settings don't work for you, they can be customized by using withCaseDelimiterChars(com.google.mu.function.CharPredicate) and/or withLowerCaseChars(com.google.mu.function.CharPredicate).

    Since:
    6.0

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      CaseBreaker()  

    • Method Summary

      Modifier and Type Method Description
      java.util.stream.Stream<java.lang.String> breakCase​(java.lang.CharSequence text)
      Returns a lazy stream of words split out from text, delimited by non-letter-digit ascii characters, and further split at lowerCamelCase and UpperCamelCase boundaries.
      CaseBreaker withCaseDelimiterChars​(CharPredicate caseDelimiter)
      Returns a new instance using caseDelimiter to identify case delimiter characters, for example if you need to respect CJK caseDelimiter characters.
      CaseBreaker withLowerCaseChars​(CharPredicate camelLower)
      Returns a new instance using camelLower to identify lower case characters (don't forget to include digits if they should also be treated as lower case).

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

      • breakCase

        public java.util.stream.Stream<java.lang.String> breakCase​(java.lang.CharSequence text)
        Returns a lazy stream of words split out from text, delimited by non-letter-digit ascii characters, and further split at lowerCamelCase and UpperCamelCase boundaries.

        Examples: 

        
 breakCase("userId") => ["user", "Id"]
 breakCase("field_name") => ["field", "name"]
 breakCase("CONSTANT_NAME") => ["CONSTANT", "NAME"]
 breakCase("dash-case") => ["dash", "case"]
 breakCase("3 separate words") => ["3", "separate", "words"]
 breakCase("TheURLs") => ["The", "URLs"]
 breakCase("ðŸ…£â“—â“”ðŸ…¤ðŸ…¡ðŸ…›â“¢") => ["ðŸ…£â“—â“”", "ðŸ…¤ðŸ…¡ðŸ…›â“¢""]
 breakCase("UpgradeIPv4ToIPv6") => ["Upgrade", "IPv4", "To", "IPv6"]

        Besides used as case delimiters, non-letter-digit ascii characters are filtered out from the returned words.
